name: EmilyAOSE
comment info:
The graph represents the average temperature over the course of 1880-2020 compared to the average temperature in the mid-20th century. The blue represents a decrease in temperatures while the orange represents an increase in temperature. The dark orange represents the sharp increase in temperature that has occurred in recent years.

The drastic changes in the temperatures were caused by climate change. I wonder what happened in the years leading up to 2022 that caused such a sharp increase in temperature. I also wonder why there is so much fluctuation in temperature around 1950. 

1950 was the first year that CO2 readings occurred. Therefore, this is the year used for the baseline of the temperature comparisons. Prior to 1950 there were much lower temperatures. However, I observe that this trend began to change in 1940. This may a result of the increased use of petroleum as a result of the second industrial revolution in 1917. Beginning in 1980, there had been a gradual increase in temperature every year. This was when climate change was beginning to be recognized as an issue.

This effects me and my community because the rising temperatures of climate change are already being felt. For instance, in recent years there has been a significant increase in wildfires and natural disasters.

Headline: "Temperatures On The Rise"

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Nasha Palsetia --

The graph is dramatic, but it isn’t a histogram.  A histogram shows the distribution (how frequent something happens) of a variable.  You’re familiar with histograms. name: Naomi C.
comment info:
Up 'till around 1940, the global average temperature was consistently below the 1951-1980 average temperature. This makes sense, as that pre-1940 period was not included in the calculations to find the global temperature referral point. The years which were used to find the referral line (global temperature average) had temperature's that fluctuated quite a bit, so they formed the relatively stable-ish years and were a transition from the colder pre 1940 temperatures to the warmer post 1981 years. While both domains were two ends of the warm-cool spectrum, the warmer years had temperatures that increased more rapidly than the preceding colder time period. 
Why are there these marked cold and hot periods in time? What caused the fluctuations between the years 1941 and 1980? What is the impact of each increasing Celsius degree? What caused the temperature growth after the 1981s? Would the increasing warmth melt ice, and what would that do to the animals that live near the poles?
There have been a few storms recently in the area, but how is global warming going to affect weather? Will big storms become commonplace in some areas and in others extreme drought? What preparations will need to be taken? It definitely looks like things are only going to get hotter, too. 
Headline: The World's Getting Hotter - Bring Ice Cream and the Polar Bears

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Lauren R. --

Thank you for your very thoughtful response.  

I never heard of a Keeling Curve, but I looked it up.  What seems to distinguish a Keeling Curve is that it fluctuates by the season.  Levels rise in the fall and winter and fall in spring and summer.  And, these fluctuations are rather regular.  Is that what this graph shows?  

You ask how NASA (and others) collected this data.  That is a very important question.  By Friday, we will reveal a free link to the article that includes this graph.  There, you will find both a short explanation of how the data is collected and a link to NASA’s website with a more complete explanation.
